Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Seismic interferometry and reflection imaging of the deep crust
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research aims to merge methods of academic passive source seismology with industry active source seismology for enhanced subsurface seismic imaging at a variety of scales. The emerging methods of seismic interferometry will be explored and applied. Work on the proposed project will be used to improve corrections for near-surface variations, develop schemes for incorporating virtual source methods into seismic reflection imaging, and to further utilize seismic data sets collected in the past. Methods will be applied both to sedimentary basins of economic interest and to deep Rocky Mountain fault systems, with implications for crustal deformation processes and origin of the deep structures that formed the Rocky Mountains. The collaboration with industry will benefit the project through access to computer hardware and software, and to industry signal processing and large data set expertise.

In this project the utility of including virtual source gathers and velocity structures derived from interferometry in seismic reflection studies will be explored. The two main approaches that will be followed include development and comparison of near-surface statics corrections derived from surface wave ambient noise tomography to those from traditional refraction statics, and active source interferometry applied to reflection surveys. Rather than restricting the interferometry to ambient background noise, the virtual source methods take advantage of waveform recordings of signals such as active source blasts, mine blasts, and distant and local earthquakes. The study will utilize a modern data set from a combined active-passive seismic experiment (Bighorn Arch Seismic Experiment or BASE), and a 1970?s era vibroseis data set (COCORP Wind River mountains experiment). The main geologic targets in each case are the deep faults beneath the Laramide Arches and flanking basement, including suggested crustal detachment features widely invoked in structural models. The proposed contributions will be of general use beyond this particular geologic environment and geographic province, and will more fully exploit existing data sets. A comparison of resulting images from this proposed study can provide an opportunity to evaluate the effectiveness of each imaging method with diverse data sets, and the accompanying active source experiments provide an important check on results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an academic-industry collaboration to explore the use the signals from distant earthquakes to image the Earth’s crust in north central Wyoming and to use petroleum industry methods to perform deep crustal imaging of thick-skinned foreland arches.

Methods to use seismic arrivals from distant earthquakes (teleseismic autocorrelation interferometry) were developed and applied to data recorded by large numbers of instruments (high frequency single component seismometer), as part of the Bighorn Arch seismic experiment. Application of these methods to signals from thirty teleseisms (distant earthquakes) were successful in revealing reflections from bedrock at the base of the deep sedimentary basins that flank the Bighorn Mountains in Wyoming. 

Use of interferometric seismic processing methods with active source explosive sources from the Bighorn Arch seismic experiment were performed. Fourteen active source (explosive) shots and 1300 recording instruments were used. With this work each geophone is treated as a virtual source and cross-correlation between data recorded at the virtual source point and at the other geophones is performed for each shot and stacked to produce a virtual source gather. The results showed meaningful arrivals but the approach was less effective than in the previously published active source interferometry using ocean bottom cable offshore data, and the source of these differences was explored. Issues of stationary phase contributed to difficulty in resolving reflections in the land case, related to having the seismic sources and receivers on the same plane. The land active source interferometry virtual source gathers were used to increase the fold in reflection imaging using the industry software, but were inferior to the traditional active source images. A careful comparison of the onshore and offshore results was performed. 

Broader impacts of the work included training of a graduate student and an undergraduate intern in methods of reflection seismology and time series analysis. The academic/industry collaboration explored the use of academic passive source seismology with industry active source seismology for enhancing subsurface imaging. The methods were found to be able to resolve large scale basin thickness, of utility in academic and industry applications. The methods did not resolve detailed structure within or beneath the basin, and reasons for this as well as directions for future study were explored.
